Provision.Text: His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, pursuant to section 32 of the Secure Air Travel Acta, makes the annexed Secure Air Travel Regulations.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: Act means the Secure Air Travel Act.
boarding pass includes a ticket or other document that is both accepted by an air carrier and approved by an aerodrome operator as confirmation of the holder’s status as a passenger on a flight.

Section.Text: These Regulations apply in respect of the following passenger-carrying flights if the passengers are subject to screening that is carried out — in Canada, by the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority or, in another country, by the person or entity responsible for the screening of persons and goods in that country — before boarding:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: domestic flights that depart from Canadian aerodromes and that are conducted by air carriers under Subpart 5 of Part VII of the Canadian Aviation Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: international flights that depart from or will arrive at Canadian aerodromes and that are conducted by air carriers

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: under Subpart 1 of Part VII of the Canadian Aviation Regulations using aircraft that have a maximum certificated take-off weight of more than 8 618 kg (19,000 pounds) or have a seating configuration, excluding crew seats, of 20 or more, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: under Subpart 5 of Part VII of the Canadian Aviation Regulations.

Subsection.Text: An air carrier must accept only the following identification to verify the identity of a passenger for a domestic flight:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one piece of valid photo identification that is issued by a government authority and that shows the passenger’s name, date of birth and gender;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two pieces of valid identification that are issued by a government authority, at least one of which shows the passenger’s name, date of birth and gender; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a restricted area identity card, as defined in section 3 of the Canadian Aviation Security Regulations, 2012.

Subsection.Text: An air carrier must accept only the following identification to verify the identity of a passenger for an international flight:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one piece of valid photo identification that is issued by a government authority and that shows the passenger’s name, date of birth and gender; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a restricted area identity card, as defined in section 3 of the Canadian Aviation Security Regulations, 2012.

Section.Text: Despite section 3, an air carrier may use alternative forms of identification — including employee identity cards, public transit passes and baptismal certificates — to verify the identity of a person for the purpose of sections 5 and 6 if the person presents documentation that is issued by a government authority or a police service and that attests to the loss or theft of the required identification.

Subsection.Text: An air carrier must, before issuing a boarding pass to any person who appears to be 18 years of age or older, verify the identity of the person by comparing their name with the names of listed persons.
If the name of the person is the same as that of a listed person,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air carrier must not allow the person to obtain a boarding pass at a kiosk or from the Internet; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air carrier must compare the name, date of birth and gender on the person’s identification to those of the listed person.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Duty to inform Minister of Transport
Subsection.Text: If the name, date of birth and gender on the identification are the same as those of a listed person, the air carrier must immediately inform the Minister of Transport.

After informing the Minister of Transport, the air carrier must not issue a boarding pass to the person unless the Minister of Transport has informed the air carrier that a direction referred to in paragraph 9(1)(a) of the Act will not be made in respect of that person.

An air carrier must, at a boarding gate for a flight, verify the age of each passenger taking the flight by looking at the passenger, and in particular their entire face, to determine if they appear to be 18 years of age or older.
The air carrier must verify the identity of each passenger who appears to be 18 years of age or older by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: comparing the passenger, and in particular their entire face, with their identification; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: comparing the name on the passenger’s boarding pass with their identification.

Subsection.Text: It is prohibited for an air carrier to transport a passenger if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the passenger presents a piece of photo identification and does not resemble the photograph;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the passenger does not appear to be the age indicated by the date of birth on the identification presented;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the passenger does not appear to be of the gender indicated on the identification presented; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the passenger presents more than one form of identification and there is a major discrepancy between those forms of identification.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(a), an air carrier may transport a passenger who presents a piece of photo identification but does not resemble the photograph if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the passenger’s appearance changed for medical reasons after the photograph was taken and the passenger presents the air carrier with a document signed by a health care professional that attests to that fact; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the passenger’s face is bandaged for medical reasons and the passenger presents the air carrier with a document signed by a health care professional that attests to that fact.

Subsection.Text: If there is a major discrepancy between the name on the identification presented by a passenger and the name on the passenger’s boarding pass, an air carrier must compare the name, date of birth and gender on the identification with those of listed persons.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Duty to inform Minister of Transport
Subsection.Text: If the name, date of birth and gender on the identification are the same as those of a listed person, the air carrier must immediately inform the Minister of Transport.

Section.Text: It is prohibited for an air carrier to transport a person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: about whom the Minister of Transport has been informed under subsection 8(2), unless the Minister of Transport has informed the air carrier that a direction referred to in section 9 of the Act will not be made in respect of that person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: about whom a direction has been made, unless the air carrier has complied with the direction.

Section.Text: If a direction is made under paragraph 9(1)(a) of the Act in respect of a listed person, the Minister of Transport must provide the air carrier with contact information for the administrative recourse office of the Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness and the air carrier must make that contact information available to the person.

An air carrier must ensure that any system it uses to comply with sections 5 to 8 uses only the most up-to-date information provided to the air carrier by the Minister of Transport respecting listed persons.

If the Minister of Transport informs an air carrier that a person is no longer a listed person, the air carrier must immediately remove all information respecting that person from any system it uses to comply with sections 5 to 8.
An air carrier must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: access to information respecting listed persons is restricted to air carrier employees, representatives or contractors who require the access to carry out their duties under the Act or these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: access by those employees, representatives or contractors is limited to the extent necessary to carry out those duties.

Section.Text: It is prohibited for air carrier employees, representatives or contractors to use any information respecting a listed person except to the extent necessary to carry out their duties under the Act or these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: An air carrier must keep an up-to-date record of all employees, representatives or contractors of the air carrier who have access to the list established under subsection 8(1) of the Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Provision of list to Minister of Transport
Subsection.Text: The air carrier must provide the up-to-date record to the Minister of Transport on reasonable notice given by that Minister.

Section.Text: These Regulations come into force on August 1, 2015.
